topic.title: MAPOTN Overview

body.p: MAPOTN is a mapping engine that maps various packet and CBR payloads into suitable ODUk containers for transport over OTN. The MAPOTN supports GFP-F, GMP, BMP, IMP and BGMP mappings. The MAPOTN performs OPU (Optical Channel Payload Unit) overhead extraction and consequential actions processing. The MAPOTN has three bidirectional interfaces:

li.p: DCPB Interface is client interface to COPI (PIF)PIF.
ENET (ECPB) Interface is client interface for Ethernet.

body.p: The MAPOTN is capable of processing up to total 120 channels concurrently, with maximum aggregated bandwidth of 600G, and allows mapping and demapping of packet and/or CBR traffic. In addition to mapping and de-mapping, the MAPOTN performs filtering, performance monitoring, and scheduling of the packet and CBR traffic.

The MAPOTN allows for the transport of a large number of protocols over an OTN network. A packet client of any rate equal or below 100G bps from the DCPB (Datapath Central Packet Buffer), or ECPB (ENET) can be GFP-F mapped and then placed into an ODUk container. 100GE Ethernet/FlexE can be GMP mapped into ODU4. BMP/IMP mapping are supported for 10GE/25GE/50GE/200GE/400GE and IMP for any FlexE client rate. FlexE aware clients can be mapped using BGMP transport mapping.

The incoming client payload is inserted into the OPUk payload area. The mapping engines fill in all of the OPUk OH bytes with the exception of the PSI byte. For GFP, GMP, BMP and IMP mappings, only the PT and CSF fields of the PSI are filled. For BGMP, PT, CSF and PSI[3..3+p] are filled as per G.798 adaptation functions in section 14.3.18 of ITU-T Recommendation G.798.1, “Types and characteristics of optical transport network equipment”, January 2013.http://bby1dms01/DocMgmt/fileinfo.cfm?file_id=369431 . Only place holders are inserted for ODUk OH bytes except for the FAS and MFAS fields. The OTN trail termination source and sink functions are implemented in the COREOTN subsystem.

The GFP-F mapper can accept packet data from both the DCPB and ECPB, along with a corresponding channel ID and UPI field. The GFP-F mapper inserts the PLI, cHEC, TYPE header, tHEC and optional Payload FCS with correct values and then maps the GFP-F frame into an OPUk payload area. If no client packets are available for transmission, GFP idle frames are transmitted between GFP client frames until the GFP mapper receives new packet data.

The GFP-F de-mapper removes the ODU and OPU overhead bytes and extracts the GFP frame. It also removes the GFP Core and Type header encapsulation and then forwards the data to the DCPB and/or the ECPB. Various checks like HEC and FCS are performed and the results are reported. Packets are dropped in case of any HEC errors in the GFP de-mapper and counted. Any received GFP IDLE frames are deleted by GFP de-mapper. The GFP de-mapper supports filtering of packets based on GFP header bytes in the incoming frame for the purpose of directing client management frames to the device firmware for implementing trunk to client consequential actions and data frames to the downstream subsystem for termination.

GMP mapper introduces stuff locations inside the OPUk container to accommodate for the rate differences between client signal and server container. Client mapping scheme is controlled by SW configuration.

The GMP de-mapper removes the ODU and OPU overhead bytes, extracts the client CBR data from the incoming OPUk payload area and forwards the client CBR data to IMP_D block, which performs BIP checking prior to descrambling the OPUk traffic. The GMP de-mapper also performs CRC checking and reports the status.

IMP_M decodes incoming packets into a stream of codewords, performs idle insertion and scrambles the traffic. BMP engine supports TDM channels using either BMP or BGMP mapping and maps the clients into ODU2e/ODU1e(BMP) container or ODUflex(BMP/BGMP). The rate is controlled by SW configuration.

The BMP de-mapper is a CBR de-mapping engine. It removes the ODU and OPU overhead bytes, extracts the client CBR data from the incoming OPUk payload. IMP_D optionally processes incoming codewords into a stream of packets.
